definition: A document that formally authorizes a project and defines its objectives, scope, and stakeholders.
example: The sponsor signed the project charter to officially start the initiative.

definition: The boundaries of a project, describing what is included and excluded in the work.
example: Clearly defining the scope helps prevent misunderstandings later.

definition: Uncontrolled changes or growth in a project’s scope without adjustments to time, cost, or resources.
example: Frequent new requests from stakeholders caused scope creep.

definition: Any person or group that can impact or is impacted by a project.
example: Identifying key stakeholders early helped align expectations.

definition: A tangible or intangible output produced as a result of project activities.
example: The final report is the main deliverable of this project phase.

definition: A significant point or event in a project’s timeline used to monitor progress.
example: Completing user testing is a major milestone before launch.

definition: A hierarchical decomposition of the total project work into smaller, manageable components.
example: The team used a WBS to organize tasks into work packages.

definition: The longest sequence of tasks that determines the shortest possible project duration.
example: Delays on the critical path will delay the entire project.

definition: A relationship between tasks where one activity relies on the output of another.
example: Design approval is a dependency before development can begin.

definition: The approved version of a plan used as a reference to measure project performance.
example: We compare actual costs against the budget baseline each month.

definition: A series of phases that a project goes through from initiation to closure.
example: Our project lifecycle includes discovery, design, build, and launch.

definition: An iterative project management approach focused on collaboration, flexibility, and continuous delivery.
example: The team adopted Agile to respond quickly to changing requirements.

definition: An Agile framework that uses fixed-length iterations called sprints to deliver value incrementally.
example: In Scrum, the team plans the work for each sprint during sprint planning.

definition: A short, time-boxed period in which a Scrum team completes a set amount of work.
example: The team aims to deliver a releasable increment every sprint.

definition: An ordered list of features, enhancements, and fixes that represent future work on a product.
example: The product owner prioritizes items in the product backlog.

definition: The list of product backlog items selected for a sprint, plus a plan for delivering them.
example: The sprint backlog defines the team’s work for the next two weeks.

definition: A visual workflow method that limits work in progress to improve flow and efficiency.
example: The team uses a Kanban board to track tasks through each stage.

definition: A bar chart that shows project tasks over time and illustrates their start and end dates.
example: The project manager updated the Gantt chart to reflect the new deadlines.

definition: An uncertain event or condition that, if it occurs, has a positive or negative impact on objectives.
example: Identifying risks early helps the team plan responses.

definition: A problem that is currently affecting the project and requires immediate attention.
example: The supplier delay became a critical issue for the timeline.

definition: A document that lists identified risks, their analysis, and planned responses.
example: We review the risk register in every status meeting.

definition: A formal proposal to modify a project’s scope, schedule, or budget.
example: The client submitted a change request for additional features.

definition: A structured process for evaluating and approving changes to a project.
example: Change control ensures that only justified changes are implemented.

definition: A senior person who provides resources, support, and overall direction for a project.
example: The project sponsor resolved conflicts between departments.

definition: The person responsible for planning, executing, and closing a project.
example: The project manager facilitated communication across the whole team.

definition: A document that describes how the project will be executed, monitored, and closed.
example: The project plan outlines milestones, resources, and risks.

definition: The relationship between scope, time, and cost that shapes project outcomes.
example: Changing the scope will affect the triple constraint and likely impact cost.

definition: A factor considered to be true for planning purposes, without full proof.
example: An assumption in the plan is that key staff will be available.

definition: A limiting factor that affects the execution of a project.
example: The fixed launch date is a major constraint for the team.

definition: The process of assigning people, budget, and tools to project tasks.
example: Effective resource allocation avoids overloading team members.

definition: The process of identifying stakeholders and understanding their interests and influence.
example: Stakeholder analysis helped prioritize communication efforts.

definition: A document that defines how information will be shared with stakeholders.
example: The communication plan specifies who receives status reports and when.

definition: A regular update on project progress, risks, and issues.
example: The weekly status report keeps stakeholders informed.

definition: The first meeting where the project team and stakeholders align on objectives and expectations.
example: During the kick-off meeting, everyone agreed on the project timeline.

definition: Insights gained from project experiences that can improve future work.
example: We documented lessons learned to avoid similar issues in the next project.

definition: The final phase where the project is formally completed and handed over.
example: Project closure included a final review and handover to operations.

definition: Conditions that must be met for a deliverable to be accepted by the customer.
example: The team validated features against the acceptance criteria.

definition: Activities focused on ensuring that project processes will produce quality results.
example: Quality assurance reviews verify that standards are followed.

definition: Activities that check whether deliverables meet quality requirements.
example: The team ran quality control tests before releasing the product.

definition: A measure of work performed expressed in terms of the budget authorized.
example: Earned value analysis showed that the project was behind schedule.

definition: The estimated cost of completing a project.
example: Staying within budget was a key objective for the sponsor.

definition: The amount by which actual project costs exceed the budget.
example: Late changes to requirements caused a cost overrun.

definition: A fixed period of time reserved for a specific activity.
example: The team used a two-hour timebox for backlog refinement.

definition: The ongoing process of reviewing and updating items in the product backlog.
example: Backlog refinement helps keep upcoming work clear and sized.

definition: A short daily meeting where the team synchronizes work and identifies obstacles.
example: During the daily stand-up, each member shared their progress.

definition: A meeting held at the end of an iteration to reflect on what went well and what can improve.
example: In the retrospective, the team agreed to improve estimation practices.

definition: A short description of a feature from the perspective of an end user.
example: The product owner wrote a user story to capture the login requirement.

definition: A relative unit used by teams to estimate the effort required for a user story.
example: The team assigned five story points to the new feature.

definition: A graph showing the remaining work in a sprint or project over time.
example: The burn-down chart indicated that the team was ahead of schedule.

definition: A graph that shows work completed over time and highlights total scope.
example: The burn-up chart made it easy to see scope changes.

definition: The simplest version of a product that can be released to test assumptions and gather feedback.
example: The team focused on building an MVP for early user testing.

definition: A high-level visual summary that maps out the vision and direction of a product over time.
example: The product roadmap shows planned releases for the next year.

definition: The process of collecting needs and expectations from stakeholders.
example: Workshops were used for requirements gathering with end users.

definition: A description of how a user interacts with a system to achieve a goal.
example: The analyst documented use cases for the new booking system.

definition: Actions taken to reduce the likelihood or impact of a risk.
example: Hiring an extra developer was a risk mitigation strategy.

definition: A backup plan that outlines what to do if identified risks occur.
example: The contingency plan covered potential system outages.

definition: The process of raising an issue to higher authority for resolution.
example: The project manager initiated escalation when the vendor missed deadlines.

definition: A chart that defines who is responsible, accountable, consulted, and informed for each task.
example: The RACI matrix clarified decision-making roles across teams.

definition: A detailed description of the project scope, deliverables, and acceptance criteria.
example: The project scope statement was shared with all stakeholders.

definition: The smallest unit of work in a WBS that can be assigned and managed.
example: Each work package was assigned to a specific team lead.

definition: A delay between dependent tasks where the successor starts later than the predecessor finishes.
example: There is a two-day lag between testing and deployment.

definition: The amount of time between the start of a process and its completion.
example: Reducing lead time helped deliver features faster.

definition: A technique to smooth resource usage by adjusting task start and end dates.
example: Resource leveling reduced overtime by shifting non-critical tasks.

definition: The start of project execution when the team begins working on tasks.
example: After the planning phase, the project kickoff marked the start of delivery.

definition: The framework of rules and processes that guide project decision-making.
example: Strong project governance ensured consistent decisions across portfolios.

definition: A group of related projects managed in a coordinated way to achieve benefits.
example: Several IT projects were combined into a single program.

definition: A collection of projects and programs managed together to meet strategic goals.
example: The leadership team reviewed the entire project portfolio quarterly.

definition: The process of ensuring that project outcomes deliver the expected business value.
example: Benefit realization was tracked six months after go-live.

definition: The person responsible for monitoring and responding to a specific risk.
example: Each major risk was assigned a risk owner on the team.

definition: A document used to track project issues, their status, and actions taken.
example: The issue log is reviewed in every weekly meeting.

definition: Limitations related to time, cost, scope, or quality that affect the project.
example: The team had to plan around strict project constraints.

definition: A record of assumptions made during planning and execution.
example: We updated the assumptions log when the vendor changed their delivery date.

definition: Gradual expansion of project scope without formal approval or resource changes.
example: Uncontrolled feature requests led to project scope creep.

definition: Formal confirmation by the sponsor that a key decision or deliverable is accepted.
example: The team waited for project sponsor approval before moving to the next phase.

definition: A recurring meeting to review progress, risks, and next steps.
example: The weekly project status meeting helps keep everyone aligned.

definition: A tool for tracking risks, assumptions, issues, and dependencies in one place.
example: The RAID log gave a clear overview of project challenges.

definition: The approved version of the project scope statement, WBS, and WBS dictionary.
example: Changes to the scope baseline require formal approval.

definition: The approved version of the project schedule used for comparison.
example: Delays were measured against the schedule baseline.

definition: The approved budget for the project, excluding management reserves.
example: Actual spending was tracked against the cost baseline.

definition: A record of all changes requested, approved, or rejected in the project.
example: The change log shows how scope evolved over time.

definition: A document that lists stakeholders and includes details such as their interests, influence, and contact information.
example: The stakeholder register helped the team tailor communication to each audience.

definition: A plan that describes how to involve stakeholders in project decisions and activities.
example: The stakeholder engagement plan outlined touchpoints for key sponsors and users.

definition: A collaborative session where key stakeholders define and agree on the project’s purpose and boundaries.
example: During the project charter workshop, the team clarified objectives and success criteria.

definition: A concise summary of a project’s goals, scope, and constraints used to align stakeholders.
example: The agency shared a project brief with the client before detailed planning.

definition: A document describing how the project scope will be defined, validated, and controlled.
example: The scope management plan specified who could approve scope changes.

definition: A plan that defines how the project schedule will be developed, monitored, and controlled.
example: The schedule management plan set rules for updating milestones and dependencies.

definition: A plan that outlines how project costs will be estimated, budgeted, and controlled.
example: The cost management plan required monthly forecasts from each workstream.

definition: A document that specifies quality standards, metrics, and quality assurance and control activities.
example: The quality management plan defined defect thresholds for release.

definition: A plan describing how human and physical resources will be acquired, developed, and managed.
example: The resource management plan identified critical skills needed each quarter.

definition: A document that defines communication goals, channels, frequency, and responsibilities.
example: The communications management plan scheduled monthly newsletters for stakeholders.

definition: A plan that describes how risk identification, analysis, and responses will be conducted.
example: The risk management plan required owners and due dates for all major risks.

definition: A document that defines how goods and services will be acquired from outside the organization.
example: The procurement management plan outlined vendor selection criteria and timelines.

definition: A group of stakeholders responsible for reviewing and approving project change requests.
example: The change control board meets weekly to review major scope changes.

definition: A review point at the end of a project phase where continuation is approved or rejected.
example: The project passed its phase gate after meeting all design criteria.

definition: A formal decision point to proceed with or halt a project or release.
example: At the go/no-go meeting, leadership approved the product launch.

definition: A planning technique where near-term work is planned in detail and future work at a higher level.
example: The team used rolling wave planning to refine tasks as more information became available.

definition: An estimating method where overall project cost or duration is estimated first and then broken down.
example: Top-down estimating was used early when little detail was known.

definition: An estimating technique where work is broken into detailed tasks and each is estimated individually.
example: Bottom-up estimating produced a more accurate schedule for the build phase.

definition: An estimating method that uses historical data from similar projects to predict cost or duration.
example: The team used analogous estimating based on last year’s migration project.

definition: An estimating technique that uses statistical relationships between variables, such as cost per unit.
example: Parametric estimating used cost per feature to estimate the total budget.

definition: An estimating method that considers optimistic, pessimistic, and most likely values.
example: Three-point estimating helped capture uncertainty in the duration of testing.

definition: A quantitative risk analysis technique that uses random sampling to model possible outcomes.
example: Monte Carlo simulation estimated the probability of meeting the deadline.

definition: The level of risk an organization or stakeholder is willing to accept.
example: The sponsor’s low risk appetite influenced the choice of mitigation strategies.

definition: The acceptable variation in outcomes related to a specific risk.
example: The team defined a clear risk tolerance for schedule delays.

definition: The individual responsible for monitoring and managing a specific risk.
example: Each top risk in the register had an assigned risk owner.

definition: A set of actions designed to address identified risks if they occur.
example: The risk response plan included a fallback vendor for critical components.

definition: A positive risk that, if it occurs, has a beneficial impact on project objectives.
example: Securing a discount from suppliers was identified as an opportunity.

definition: A relationship where a project relies on deliverables or activities outside its direct control.
example: The integration project had a dependency on the ERP upgrade.

definition: A dependency involving tasks or events outside the project team’s authority.
example: Regulatory approval was a major external dependency for the launch.

definition: A dependency between tasks or teams within the same organization.
example: Reporting changes had an internal dependency on the data warehouse team.

definition: A Scrum event where the team decides what work to deliver in the upcoming sprint.
example: During sprint planning, the team selected stories based on capacity and priority.

definition: A Scrum event where the team presents the increment and gathers feedback from stakeholders.
example: In the sprint review, users tested new features and suggested improvements.

definition: The sum of all completed product backlog items at the end of a sprint.
example: Each increment should be in a usable state, even if not released.

definition: A shared understanding of what it means for work to be complete.
example: The team updated the Definition of Done to include performance testing.

definition: Criteria that a backlog item must meet before the team agrees to work on it.
example: Stories must meet the Definition of Ready before entering a sprint.

definition: The role responsible for maximizing the value of the product and managing the product backlog.
example: The product owner prioritized features based on customer impact.

definition: A servant leader who facilitates Scrum events and removes impediments for the team.
example: The Scrum master helped resolve a conflict about priorities.

definition: A person who guides individuals and teams in adopting Agile practices and mindset.
example: The Agile coach trained teams on Kanban and Scrum principles.

definition: The process of defining the scope and timing of product releases.
example: Release planning aligned multiple teams on the next quarter’s goals.

definition: A recurring, synchronized release cycle used in scaled Agile environments.
example: Features from all teams ship together on the quarterly release train.

definition: A timeboxed planning interval, usually 8–12 weeks, in scaled Agile frameworks.
example: During the program increment, teams worked toward shared objectives.

definition: The amount of work a team completes in a sprint, usually measured in story points.
example: The team’s velocity stabilized at around 40 points per sprint.

definition: The number of work items completed in a given period.
example: The Kanban team tracked throughput weekly to gauge performance.

definition: The time it takes for a work item to move from start to finish.
example: Reducing cycle time helped deliver features more quickly.

definition: A cap on the number of tasks that can be in a given stage at one time.
example: Setting a work in progress limit prevented the team from starting too many tasks.

definition: A horizontal or vertical section on a board that groups work items by category or owner.
example: The Kanban board used swimlanes for each product area.

definition: An impediment that prevents progress on a task or project.
example: The missing approval became a roadblock for deployment.

definition: Anything that slows down or stops the team from making progress.
example: The Scrum master tracks and removes impediments raised in stand-ups.

definition: A detailed description of project deliverables, boundaries, and acceptance criteria.
example: The project scope statement helped avoid work outside the agreed boundaries.

definition: A visual display of key project metrics such as schedule, cost, and risks.
example: Executives reviewed the project dashboard before the steering committee.

definition: A group of senior stakeholders who provide oversight and direction to the project.
example: The steering committee approved major changes to the project roadmap.

definition: A document that lists expected project benefits and how they will be measured.
example: The benefits register linked each benefit to a specific metric and owner.

definition: A justification for a project that outlines expected benefits, costs, and risks.
example: The business case showed that automation would pay back within two years.

definition: An analysis of whether a proposed project is viable technically, financially, and operationally.
example: The feasibility study concluded that the legacy system could not support the upgrade.

definition: A small-scale implementation used to test an approach before a full rollout.
example: The pilot project ran in one region before expanding globally.

definition: A small experiment designed to demonstrate that an idea or approach is workable.
example: The proof of concept validated that the integration was technically possible.

definition: An analysis of how a proposed change will affect systems, processes, and people.
example: The change impact assessment highlighted additional training needs.

definition: A plan describing how and when project benefits will be delivered and measured.
example: The benefits realization plan extended beyond the project end date.

definition: The process of transferring responsibility from the project team to operational teams.
example: Operational handover included documentation, training, and support agreements.

definition: A focused support period immediately after go-live to quickly resolve issues.
example: During hypercare, extra staff monitored the system around the clock.

definition: A detailed plan for deploying a solution across locations, users, or phases.
example: The rollout plan staged deployments by country over three months.

definition: A step-by-step plan for switching from an old system or process to a new one.
example: The cutover plan listed exact times for each migration activity.

definition: A plan describing how to revert to a previous state if the new solution fails.
example: The fallback plan allowed the team to roll back to the old system within two hours.

definition: A report that highlights deviations from planned performance.
example: An exception report was issued when costs exceeded the threshold.

definition: The allowable deviation from a target without requiring escalation.
example: The project had a cost tolerance of plus or minus five percent.

definition: Formal permission to begin work on a specific task or work package.
example: Work authorization was required before starting vendor integration.

definition: A technique to track how forecast milestone dates change over time.
example: Milestone trend analysis showed that delays were stabilizing.

definition: A period during which no new changes may be introduced.
example: A change freeze was enforced two weeks before go-live.

definition: An independent review of how a project is being managed and whether it follows standards.
example: The project audit identified gaps in risk documentation.

definition: A quick assessment of a project’s status, focusing on key risk and success factors.
example: A mid-project health check confirmed that morale and scope control were strong.
